awd_titl_txt: EAGER: Development of fluorescent sensors of temperature and iron ion concentrations around magnetic particles under the action of an oscillating magnetic field
awd_abstract_narration:
The goal of this project is to develop optical sensors to understand the mechanism of treating cancer by hyperthermia (overheating). This promising techniques is performed by first injecting magnetic nanoparticles then heating them with a magnetic field. Hyperthermia treatment is still suffering from multiple side effects, which prevent its broad use. It is currently believed that increased temperature is more toxic for cancer compared to normal tissue. In this project, the investigators will test the hypothesis that the magnetic nanoparticles actively dissolve themself under the action of the magnetic field, thereby adding chemical toxicity, which also helps kill cancer cells. To test this hypothesis, new optical sensors will be developed to measure localized temperature and iron salt concentration around the magnetic particles. The collected knowledge will be used to increase the efficiency of hyperthermia treatment of cancer and eventually decrease the side effects.  The project will also contribute to the education and research training of a female graduate student in this multidisciplinary area including nanophotonics, physics, and medicine, and results will be incorporated into “Introduction to scanning probe microscopy” and “Nano and micro mechanics” courses.

To understand the mechanism of action of hyperthermia treatment on cancer cells, ultrabright fluorescent ratiometric nanosensors of temperature and iron ions will be developed. A thin fluorescent coating of magnetic particles will be sensitive to the change of temperature and the concentrations of iron ions. Ultrahigh brightness of the photonic sensors will allow detecting the changes in temperature and ionic concentration optically, which is otherwise highly challenging. This technique will aid in the understanding of the action of the oscillating magnetic field on iron oxide magnetic nanoparticles. This understanding is important because magnetic fields are considered not only for hyperthermia treatment of cancer but for various other imaging and drug delivery techniques as well. This work will also shed light on the understanding of the photonic properties of encapsulated dyes inside of nanoporous silica matrix of the proposed nanosensors.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems

por.por_cntn:
Release of iron ions as a supplementary mechanism of action of hyperthermia treatment of cancer

Hyperthermia is a promising new cancer treatment that uses heat to destroy tumors. The heat is generated by magnetic nanoparticles made of iron oxide that are injected into the tumor. When exposed to an oscillating magnetic field, these nanoparticles heat up and raise the temperature of the cancerous tissue, killing the tumor cells. However, it's crucial to carefully control the temperature to avoid harming healthy tissue surrounding the tumor.

       In our previous research, we developed fluorescent coatings for the magnetic nanoparticles that allowed us to precisely measure their temperature. However, when we applied the oscillating magnetic field used in actual treatment, we noticed an unexpected change in the fluorescence. We hypothesized that this change of fluorescence was coming from the release of iron ions, which are coming out of iron oxide nanoparticles under the action of a magnetic field. It is important because the excessive concentration of iron ions is toxic to cells, and therefore, may be the additional mechanism of killing tumor cells. Furthermore, it is important to measure the concentration of iron ions to preserve normal tissue during such treatment.

            In this study, we successfully created such a coating and confirmed that iron ions are indeed released from the nanoparticles during magnetic hyperthermia treatment. However, the accuracy of our measurements was affected by an unforeseen phenomenon - the self-assembly and clumping together of the nanoparticles under the influence of the oscillating magnetic field. This aggregation caused changes in the observed fluorescence spectra. Furthermore, the biological significance of the observed release of iron ions is not clear because of controversial results published in the literature about the levels of toxicity of iron ions. It indicates the need for further study of the biological significance of the observed effect.

        In summary, while our new fluorescent coating allows the detection of both temperature and iron ion release during magnetic hyperthermia cancer treatment, further work is necessary to overcome the challenges posed by nanoparticle aggregation and to clarify the biological impact of the released iron ions. Addressing these issues will be key to harnessing the full potential of this promising new cancer therapy.


Last Modified: 06/20/2024
Modified by: Igor Sokolov
